The patient was provided with a copy of an after-visit summary at the conclusion of the visit.
The after-visit summary includes information pertaining to the patient's encounter, including diagnoses, vital signs, medications, and new orders, as well as a list of any any upcoming appointments and information regarding the patient's ongoing care.
The patient's medications were reviewed with the patient by the provider and were provided to the patient as an updated list of medications. The patient was instructed to inform the provider of any medication changes or discrepancies that were noted. Otherwise, the patient was instructed to continue the medications as prescribed.

LOCAL TITLE: PC - AFTERVISIT SUMMARY STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: MAR 17, 2023@09:27 ENTRY DATE: MAR 17, 2023@09:27:06 AUTHOR: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** CLINIC AFTERVISIT SUMMARY ***
MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST PATIENTR
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your healthcare. Please review this document. It may contain additional information or instructions from your care provider. _______________________________________________________________________
PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS:
Thank you for coming in
Please report for labs
Please monitor your blood pressure and blood glucose
We will meet again in 3 months
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
THIS IS YOUR MEDICATION LIST MAR 17, 2023 You should keep a copy of your medication list and bring it with you to all of your medical appointments. Please continue to take these medications as directed. Call us or send us a secure message if you start, stop, or change medications. To help your primary care team provide the safest care for you, it is important for them to know about all the medications you take, even if it's just an herbal supplement or over the counter medications.
If you have any questions, please notify an assistant before you leave. If you need to refill a medication, please call 1-888-400-8387
_______________________________________________________________________
NEW AND DISCONTINUED MEDICATIONS
Your provider has NOT prescribed any new medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
Your provider has NOT discontinued any of your medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
CONTINUED MEDICATIONS (active VA and non-VA meds)
These medications were not changed during this visit. You should continue to take them as prescribed. Active Medications ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth four times a day as needed *do Not take more than 4,000mg a day of acetaminophen From all sources due to risk of liver damage. 2) Albuterol 100/Ipratro 20Mcg 120D Po Inhl Inhale 1 spray by mouth four times a day (each inhaler Contains 120 sprays) 3) Allopurinol 100Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 4) Aspirin 325Mg Ec Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 5) Buspirone Hcl 10Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day as needed for anxiety 6) Capsaicin 0.1% Cream Apply a small amount topically twice a day 7) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet every day 8) Diphenhydramine Hcl 25Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth four times a day as needed 9) Fluoxetine Hcl 10Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 10) Fluticas 500/Salmeterol 50 Inhl Disk 60 Inhale 1 inhalation by mouth twice a day rinse mouth and Spit after use. Discard 1 month after opening foil pouch. 11) Folic Acid 1Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 12) Glipizide 5Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day for diabetes. Take 30 Minutes before a meal. 13) Hydrochlorothiazide 25Mg Tab Take two tablets by mouth every morning for blood pressure 14) Hydrocortisone 1% Cream Apply thin film topically every day 15) Ibuprofen 400Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth three times a day as needed 16) Insulin Reg 100U/ml Inj 10Ml Vl Inject 5 units subcutaneously as directed 17) Metformin Hcl 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 18) Metoprolol Succinate 25Mg Sa Tab Take two tablets by mouth every day 19) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day 20) Omeprazole 20Mg Ec Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 21) Pioglitazone Hcl 15Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 22) Pravastatin Na 80Mg Tab Take one-half tablet by mouth every evening to lower your Cholesterol 23) Tamsulosin Hcl 0.4Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth at bedtime 24) Tiotropium 18Mcg Inhl Cap 30 Place 1 capsule (18 mcg) in inhaler, inhale by mouth every Day replaces ipratropium (atrovent/combivent), for Inhaler use only
Active Non-VA Medications: ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 2) Amiodarone Hcl (Pacerone) 200Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 3) Aspirin Take by mouth every day 4) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 5) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day
You have 29 active medications
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Your Primary Care Provider is: Unknown
#FUTURE APPOINTMENTS: Future Appointments: No future appointments on file
#LABS that were ordered today: No pending labs.
#IMAGING STUDIES that were ordered in the last 3 months: NO recent pending Radiology found.
+ If an imaging study (ultrasound, CT, MRI, etc) has been ordered, please call the Portland VA Medical Center Imaging Scheduling number to make arrangements: 503-273-5126.
#CONSULTS or PROCEDURES that were ordered in the past week: NO recent pending Consults found.
Your health care team may have discussed whether or not you were exposed to any potential toxins/hazards during your military service during this visit.
This is related to a new Toxic Exposure Screening (TES) program in the VA. If you believe you were exposed to potential toxins/hazards during your service, you can go here to learn more about what the VA is doing to support our Veterans: https://www.warrelatedillness.va.gov/WARRELATEDILLNESS/education/local-off erings/support/ToxicExposureScreeningEnglish.pdf
If you believe you were exposed to agent orange, burn pits, other airborne hazards, radiation, or served in Gulf War theaters, you may be eligible to participate in a free registry exam. You may call 503-906-5100 for more information.
For Healthcare Eligibility and Enrollment questions, contact our Enrollment Office at 503-273-5069.
For questions about Benefits and Claims you can find a Veteran Service Organization Office near you at: https://www.ebenefits.va.gov/ebenefits/vso-search or by calling VBA 1-800-827-1000.
If you are interested in physical therapy, please call the number below to arrange an appointment: All clinics: (503)273-5018
Your vitals for today are: Blood Pressure - 125/80 (01/08/2020 14:27) Weight - 255 lb [115.67 kg] (01/08/2020 14:27) Pain Level - 0 (01/08/2020 14:27) _______________________________________________________________________
If you have questions or concerns after today, please contact the clinic by calling 1-800-949-1004. Select option 2 when the automated message starts.

approvedBy.name: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M
approvedBy.signature: LISA M WINTERBOTTOM, M.D. Staff Physician

TAKE 30 MINUTES BEFORE A MEAL. 14) GLUCOSTIX GLUCOSE TEST STRIP USE 1 STRIP ITEM AS ACTIVE DIRECTED 15) HYDROCHLOROTHIAZIDE 25MG TAB TAKE TWO TABLETS BY ACTIVE MOUTH EVERY MORNING FOR BLOOD PRESSURE 16) HYDROCORTISONE 1% CREAM APPLY THIN FILM TOPICALLY ACTIVE EVERY DAY 17) IBUPROFEN 400MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH THREE ACTIVE TIMES A DAY AS NEEDED 18) INSULIN REG 100U/ML INJ 10ML VL INJECT 5 UNITS ACTIVE SUBCUTANEOUSLY AS DIRECTED 19) METFORMIN HCL 500MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH ACTIVE EVERY DAY 20) METOPROLOL SUCCINATE 25MG SA TAB TAKE TWO TABLETS BY ACTIVE MOUTH EVERY DAY 21) MULTIVITAMIN CAP/TAB TAKE 1 CAP/TAB BY MOUTH EVERY ACTIVE DAY 22) NEEDLE 25G 1.5IN USE ONE ITEM AS DIRECTED ACTIVE 23) OMEPRAZOLE 20MG EC CAP TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH ACTIVE EVERY DAY 24) PIOGLITAZONE HCL 15MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH ACTIVE EVERY DAY 25) PRAVASTATIN NA 80MG TAB TAKE ONE-HALF TABLET BY MOUTH ACTIVE EVERY EVENING TO LOWER YOUR CHOLESTEROL 26) TAMSULOSIN HCL 0.4MG CAP TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH AT ACTIVE BEDTIME 27) TIOTROPIUM 18MCG INHL CAP 30 PLACE 1 CAPSULE (18 MCG) ACTIVE IN INHALER, INHALE BY MOUTH EVERY DAY REPLACES IPRATROPIUM (ATROVENT/COMBIVENT), FOR INHALER USE ONLY

LOCAL TITLE: PC - AFTERVISIT SUMMARY STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: JAN 27, 2023@11:56 ENTRY DATE: JAN 27, 2023@11:56:30 AUTHOR: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** CLINIC AFTERVISIT SUMMARY ***
MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST PATIENTR
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your healthcare. Please review this document. It may contain additional information or instructions from your care provider. _______________________________________________________________________
PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS:
Thank you for coming in.
Please continue to be active most days of the week.
Continue making healthy meal choices for your nutrition.
Let us know if you would like to come back for any vaccines.
Thank you, Dr Winterbottom
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
THIS IS YOUR MEDICATION LIST JAN 27, 2023 You should keep a copy of your medication list and bring it with you to all of your medical appointments. Please continue to take these medications as directed. Call us or send us a secure message if you start, stop, or change medications. To help your primary care team provide the safest care for you, it is important for them to know about all the medications you take, even if it's just an herbal supplement or over the counter medications.
If you have any questions, please notify an assistant before you leave. If you need to refill a medication, please call 1-888-400-8387
_______________________________________________________________________
NEW AND DISCONTINUED MEDICATIONS
Your provider has NOT prescribed any new medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
Your provider has NOT discontinued any of your medications today.
_______________________________________________________________________
CONTINUED MEDICATIONS (active VA and non-VA meds)
These medications were not changed during this visit. You should continue to take them as prescribed. Active Medications ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth four times a day as needed *do Not take more than 4,000mg a day of acetaminophen From all sources due to risk of liver damage. 2) Albuterol 100/Ipratro 20Mcg 120D Po Inhl Inhale 1 spray by mouth four times a day (each inhaler Contains 120 sprays) 3) Allopurinol 100Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 4) Aspirin 325Mg Ec Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 5) Buspirone Hcl 10Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day as needed for anxiety 6) Capsaicin 0.1% Cream Apply a small amount topically twice a day 7) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet every day 8) Diphenhydramine Hcl 25Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth four times a day as needed 9) Fluoxetine Hcl 10Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 10) Fluticas 500/Salmeterol 50 Inhl Disk 60 Inhale 1 inhalation by mouth twice a day rinse mouth and Spit after use. Discard 1 month after opening foil pouch. 11) Folic Acid 1Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 12) Glipizide 5Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth twice a day for diabetes. Take 30 Minutes before a meal. 13) Hydrochlorothiazide 25Mg Tab Take two tablets by mouth every morning for blood pressure 14) Hydrocortisone 1% Cream Apply thin film topically every day 15) Ibuprofen 400Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth three times a day as needed 16) Insulin Reg 100U/ml Inj 10Ml Vl Inject 5 units subcutaneously as directed 17) Metformin Hcl 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 18) Metoprolol Succinate 25Mg Sa Tab Take two tablets by mouth every day 19) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day 20) Omeprazole 20Mg Ec Cap Take one capsule by mouth every day 21) Pioglitazone Hcl 15Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 22) Pravastatin Na 80Mg Tab Take one-half tablet by mouth every evening to lower your Cholesterol 23) Tamsulosin Hcl 0.4Mg Cap Take one capsule by mouth at bedtime 24) Tiotropium 18Mcg Inhl Cap 30 Place 1 capsule (18 mcg) in inhaler, inhale by mouth every Day replaces ipratropium (atrovent/combivent), for Inhaler use only
Active Non-VA Medications: ============================================================ 1) Acetaminophen 500Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 2) Amiodarone Hcl (Pacerone) 200Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day 3) Aspirin Take by mouth every day 4) Clopidogrel Bisulfate 75Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth 5) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day
You have 29 active medications
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Your Primary Care Provider is: Unknown
#FUTURE APPOINTMENTS: Future Appointments: No future appointments on file
#LABS that were ordered today: No pending labs.
#IMAGING STUDIES that were ordered in the last 3 months: NO recent pending Radiology found.
+ If an imaging study (ultrasound, CT, MRI, etc) has been ordered, please call the Portland VA Medical Center Imaging Scheduling number to make arrangements: 503-273-5126.
#CONSULTS or PROCEDURES that were ordered in the past week: NO recent pending Consults found.
Your health care team may have discussed whether or not you were exposed to any potential toxins/hazards during your military service during this visit.
This is related to a new Toxic Exposure Screening (TES) program in the VA. If you believe you were exposed to potential toxins/hazards during your service, you can go here to learn more about what the VA is doing to support our Veterans: https://www.warrelatedillness.va.gov/WARRELATEDILLNESS/education/local-off erings/support/ToxicExposureScreeningEnglish.pdf
If you believe you were exposed to agent orange, burn pits, other airborne hazards, radiation, or served in Gulf War theaters, you may be eligible to participate in a free registry exam. You may call 503-906-5100 for more information.
For Healthcare Eligibility and Enrollment questions, contact our Enrollment Office at 503-273-5069.
For questions about Benefits and Claims you can find a Veteran Service Organization Office near you at: https://www.ebenefits.va.gov/ebenefits/vso-search or by calling VBA 1-800-827-1000.
If you are interested in physical therapy, please call the number below to arrange an appointment: All clinics: (503)273-5018
Your vitals for today are: Blood Pressure - 125/80 (01/08/2020 14:27) Weight - 255 lb [115.67 kg] (01/08/2020 14:27) Pain Level - 0 (01/08/2020 14:27) _______________________________________________________________________
If you have questions or concerns after today, please contact the clinic by calling 1-800-949-1004. Select option 2 when the automated message starts.

approvedBy.name: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M
approvedBy.signature: LISA M WINTERBOTTOM, M.D. Staff Physician

LOCAL TITLE: MHD - NON-VISIT NOTE STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH OUTPATIENT NOTE DATE OF NOTE: SEP 30, 2021@14:53 ENTRY DATE: SEP 30, 2021@14:53:48 AUTHOR: TURNER,ERICK H EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Here's the template I use to report the Connors scores.
RESULTS OF CAARS-SELF-REPORT: LONG VERSION
Scale Cluster T-Score
30 40 50 60 70 80 90
A Inattn/Mem ************************************ B Hyprctvty/Rstlss ************************************ C Implsvty/Lability ************************************ D Probs w Self Concpt ************************************ E DSM-IV Inattentive ************************************ F DSM-IV Hyprctv-Implsv ************************************ G DSM-IV ADHD Sx Tot ************************************ H ADHD Index ************************************
Inconsistency index total score: XX (< 8)
Comment: [summary statement re whether it looks like he/she has the dx and the type.]
I then use the delete key like this:
Scale Cluster T-Score
30 40 50 60 70 80 90
A Inattn/Mem ********************************87 B Hyprctvty/Rstlss ********************65 C Implsvty/Lability **************************75 D Probs w Self Concpt ******************61 E DSM-IV Inattentive *******************************84 F DSM-IV Hyprctv-Implsv ***********************71 G DSM-IV ADHD Sx Tot ****************************80 H ADHD Index ********************************86
etc.
/es/ ERICK H TURNER, MD Staff Psychiatrist Signed: 09/30/2021 14:58

approvedBy.name: TURNER,ERICK H
approvedBy.signature: ERICK H TURNER, MD Staff Psychiatrist

LOCAL TITLE: PC - AFTERVISIT SUMMARY STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: AUG 19, 2020@09:49 ENTRY DATE: AUG 19, 2020@09:49:05 AUTHOR: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
TEST PATIENTR MHVZZVISNTWENTY MAIN ST 20 PORTLAND
HAKALAU, HI 96710
We are mailing you this summary of your recent visit for your records. *** CLINIC AFTERVISIT SUMMARY ***
MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST PATIENTR
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your healthcare. Please review this document. It may contain additional information or instructions from your care provider. _______________________________________________________________________
PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS:
Thank you for participating in our test phone appointment today.
We reviewed your blood pressure and increased your amlodipine to 10 mg daily. We will have a follow up visit in a month to review your readings.
Please complete your labs in the next two weeks.
Please wear your cpap with all naps and sleep to help your blood pressure.
Continue to eat healthy foods and take some short walks during the day.
Thank you, Dr Winterbottom
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
THIS IS YOUR MEDICATION LIST AUG 19, 2020 You should keep a copy of your medication list and bring it with you to all of your medical appointments. Please continue to take these medications as directed. Call us or send us a secure message if you start, stop, or change medications. To help your primary care team provide the safest care for you, it is important for them to know about all the medications you take, even if it's just an herbal supplement or over the counter medications.
If you have any questions, please notify an assistant before you leave. If you need to refill a medication, please call 1-888-400-8387
_______________________________________________________________________
NEW AND DISCONTINUED MEDICATIONS
Here are NEW AND/OR CHANGED MEDICATIONS that your provider has prescribed: 1) Amlodipine Besylate 10Mg Tab Take One Tablet By Mouth Every Day For Blood Pressure
_______________________________________________________________________
These are DISCONTINUED medications that you should NO LONGER TAKE: 1) Amlodipine Besylate 5Mg Tab Take One Tablet By Mouth Every Day For Blood Pressure
_______________________________________________________________________
CONTINUED MEDICATIONS (active VA and non-VA meds)
These medications were not changed during this visit. You should continue to take them as prescribed. Active Medications ============================================================ 1) Aspirin 325Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every day as directed 2) Atorvastatin Calcium 80Mg Tab Take one tablet by mouth every evening to lower cholesterol *Avoid grapefruit products with this medicine 3) Metformin Hcl 500Mg 24Hr Sa Tab Take two tablets by mouth with your evening meal
Active Non-VA Medications: ============================================================ 1) Multivitamin Cap/tab Take 1 cap/tab by mouth every day
You have 4 active medications
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Your Primary Care Provider is: Unknown
#FUTURE APPOINTMENTS: Future Appointments: No future appointments on file
#LABS that were ordered today: PENDING LABS: HEMOGLOBIN A1C BASIC METABOLIC PANEL LIPIDS, FASTING
#IMAGING STUDIES that were ordered in the last 3 months: NO recent pending Radiology found.
+ If an imaging study (ultrasound, CT, MRI, etc) has been ordered, please call the Portland VA Medical Center Imaging Scheduling number to make arrangements: 503-273-5126.
#CONSULTS or PROCEDURES that were ordered in the past week: NO recent pending Consults found.
If you are interested in physical therapy, please call one of the numbers below to arrange an appointment: Vancouver region: (360)690-1826 All other clinics: (503)273-5018
Your vitals for today are: Blood Pressure - 125/80 (01/08/2020 14:27) Weight - 255 lb [115.9 kg] (01/08/2020 14:27) Pain Level - 0 (01/08/2020 14:27) _______________________________________________________________________
If you have questions or concerns after today, please contact the clinic by calling 1-800-949-1004. Select option 2 when the automated message starts.

approvedBy.name: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M
approvedBy.signature: LISA M WINTERBOTTOM, M.D. Staff Physician

noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS - MEDICINE MULTIDISCIPLINARY STANDARD TITLE: INTERNAL MEDICINE DISCHARGE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 20, 2020@10:55 ENTRY DATE: FEB 20, 2020@10:55:47 AUTHOR: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
___________________________________________________________
YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL FOR ___________________________________________________________ #COPD EXACERBATION: You have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a permanent lung condition that can make it hard to empty the air out of the lungs. It can lead to shortness of breath and a feeling of being tired. Sometimes the breathing troubles in COPD can get worse over a short period of time, from just a few hours up to a week or two. We call this an exacerbation, or flare up. Often this is from an infection in the breathing tubes, but sometimes we don't know why it happens.
You are being sent home with the following to treat the flare up and help keep your lungs as healthy as possible in the future:
+ Pulmonary Rehabilitation, a program with exercise and education to help improve your lung health - you will receive a separate call to plan when and where this program will happen. +Oxygen +Inhaled breathing treatments to open up your breathing tubes
It is important for you to take your COPD medications as prescribed to prevent more flare ups and to help you breathe as best as you can every day. Most importantly, if you smoke, the best thing you can do for your lung disease is to stop smoking. Let your provider know if you are interested in quitting smoking because the VA has many ways we can help you. You should also get your flu vaccination every fall and talk to your primary care provider about the pneumonia vaccination.
___________________________________________________________
Date of admission: FEB 20,2020 07:44 Date of discharge: Feb 20,2020
Your Hospital Care Team:
Attending Physician: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M No Resident Physician Assigned.
Your hospital ward and contact phone number: 503-220-8262 or 1-800-949-1004 5C, extension 56105
If you have urgent questions about your hospital stay that need to be answered in the next 1-2 business days, please call the number above to reach a member of your hospital care team for help. After 2 business days, or for questions not related to this hospital stay, your primary care team can be contacted at the number listed in the "Your Follow-Up Care Plan" section of this note.
If you have any of these symptoms please call us or go to the Emergency Department: 1. You have a temperature greater than 101.5 degrees F 2. Your symptoms worsen or do not improve 3. You experience chest pain or shortness of breath
___________________________________________________________
YOUR FOLLOW-UP CARE PLAN ___________________________________________________________
#PENDING LAB TESTS: You have no studies that are pending from this hospital visit.
#LABS TO BE COMPLETED AFTER DISCHARGE You do not need any labs to be done after this hospital visit.
#IMAGING AND OTHER STUDIES TO BE COMPLETED AFTER DISCHARGE: You do not need any imaging or other studies to be done after this hospital visit.
#FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS: You will receive a follow up call in 1-3 days from a nurse to check on how you are doing. You may also need other follow up care appointments. These will be listed below:
+FOLLOW UP CARE WITH YOUR PRIMARY CARE TEAM: You may reach your Primary Care Team by calling 1-800-949-1004
You will need an appointment with your Primary Care Team in 1-2 months to Dr Primary Care
This may be a phone or in clinic visit. Your Primary Care Team will arrange this with you. If you have not heard from your Primary Care Team in one week, call them at the number listed above.
+HOSPITAL SPECIALTY CONSULTS: You do not need to follow up with any specialist for this hospital stay
___________________________________________________________
HOW TO TAKE CARE OF YOURSELF AT HOME ___________________________________________________________ #DIET: Low Sodium (see handout) Heart Healthy Diet (see handout)
#YOUR ACTIVITY LEVEL: You may be a little tired when you first get home. Slowly increase your activity level back to what you did before you got sick. This includes walking, climbing stairs, and exercising.
Home Oxygen:
You are going home with a prescription for oxygen. You are to use:
2 liters per minute when resting
3 liters per minute with activity
2 liters per minute when sleeping
Other:
If needed, a portable oxygen tank will be given to you for the trip home.
Please read the safety information in the "Handbook for Oxygen Therapy".
The oxygen vendor will visit you at home to give you the equipment you need.
#SUPPORT WE ORDERED FOR YOU AT HOME: Home Health You should be contacted by the VA or the community agency who will be providing your care in the next week. They will schedule a first in home meeting with you at that time. If you have not heard from the VA or the community agency in the next week, please call 503-220-8262 extension 31739 or 1-800-949-1004 extension 31739 for help.
#VETERANS CRISIS LINE: Dealing with illness can be a difficult experience. You are not alone. If you are in emotional distress or having thoughts of harming yourself, you should:
1. Come to the Portland VA Emergency Department, or 2. Call 911, or 3. Call the Veterans Crisis Line at 800-273-8255 (TALK); remember to press 1 as a Veteran, or Send a text message to 838255
#ADVANCED CARE PLANNING: When you are seriously ill, it is very important to make sure your loved ones and doctors know what kinds of medical treatment you want when you approach the end of your life. Physician Orders for Life-Sustaining Treatment (POLST) can help do just that.
POLST is a form that clearly states what kinds of medical treatment patients want toward the end of their lives. We completed a POLST for you during this admission. It is scanned into your health record. If you want to make changes to it in the future, your primary care team can help you.
--------------------------------------------------------------------- This discharge plan was developed by your Hospital Care Team, and the supervising physician agrees with the plan as outlined in this note. ---------------------------------------------------------------------
/es/ LISA M WINTERBOTTOM, M.D. Staff Physician Signed: 02/20/2020 11:07

approvedBy.name: WINTERBOTTOM,LISA M
approvedBy.signature: LISA M WINTERBOTTOM, M.D. Staff Physician

noteTO.standardTitle: SUICIDE PREVENTION RISK ASSESSMENT SCREENING NOTE
noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: SUICIDE RISK EVALUATION - COMPREHENSIVE STANDARD TITLE: SUICIDE PREVENTION RISK ASSESSMENT SCREENING NOT DATE OF NOTE: OCT 19, 2018@17:45 ENTRY DATE: OCT 19, 2018@17:45:26 AUTHOR: TURNER,ERICK H EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Comprehensive Suicide Risk Evaluation _____________________________________ This is a new suicide risk evaluation. The validity of the information contained within this evaluation is in question due to: Describe: thinks he's already in the afterlife, so S/A wouldn't constitute killing himself
Suicidal Ideation _________________ The most recent thoughts of engaging in suicide-related behavior were within the past 1 to 7 days. Describe the thoughts: OD The frequency of the thoughts are/were less than once a week. The Veteran does/did have a plan. Describe: OD The Veteran does have access to the lethal means described in the plan. Describe: still has The Veteran does not have access to other lethal means. The Veteran does/did not have suicidal intent.
Suicide Attempts ___________________________ The Veteran has made the following number of prior suicide attempts. Number of prior attempts: 3 The most recent suicide attempt was more than a year A reported method used for this event was an overdose of the following substance(s): Benzodiazepine Other/Non-Opioid pharmaceuticals Comment: blah As a result of this recent attempt, the Veteran was taken to or sought help at the following places: Other: Comment: ljlj The suicide attempt was not interrupted. The attempt did not result in injury. It is unknown or was not reported if the most recent suicide attempt was the most lethal attempt. Describe: ljljl The Veteran has engaged in preparatory behavior. Explain: jlj
Warning Signs _____________ Direct warning signs: N/A Indirect warning signs: Anger Anxiety Feeling Trapped Guilt or Shame Mood Changes
The following warnings signs are currently present:
Risk Factors ____________ Access to Lethal Means History of Suicide Attempt(s) Psychological Conditions Social/Systemic Problems
Protective Factors and Reasons for Living _________________________________________ Other Comment: ;lkjl;j
Clinical Impressions: ____________________ The clinical impression of acute risk is Intermediate Risk. As evidenced by: kjlkj The clinical impression of chronic risk is Intermediate Risk. As evidenced by: gggg Risk Mitigation Plan: General Strategies for Managing Risk in any setting: Increase frequency of outpatient contacts Medication reconciliation
Re-evaluation: Due to the dynamic nature of some warning signs, risk and protective factors, suicide risk should be routinely re-evaluated. These risk management strategies were chosen to address Veteran's current presentation and feasible treatment options within the system of care. This plan should be re-evaluated over time.
/es/ ERICK H TURNER, MD Staff Psychiatrist Signed: 10/19/2018 18:02

approvedBy.name: TURNER,ERICK H
approvedBy.signature: ERICK H TURNER, MD Staff Psychiatrist

noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING DATE OF NOTE: OCT 19, 2018@11:58:33 ENTRY DATE: OCT 19, 2018@09:58:33 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING Has ADDENDA ***
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 10/19/2018 12:58 PM From: DOUGLAS, DAVID To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: We have been unable to contact you
October 19, 2018 Attn: V3-PCD
XXXXX XXXXX XXXXX
Dear Veteran:
The Community Care Division is following-up regarding a VA Portland Health Care System authorization you received for a purchased care consult regarding Chiropractic Care. We have been unsuccessful in reaching you at your listed phone number. If we do not hear back from you prior to November 2, 2018 your authorization for this community procedure will be cancelled. This is necessary in order to provide needed services to other Veterans. Should you desire to continue this episode of community care, you must contact the VA Community Care Division at 360-759-1674 by the date listed to make the appropriate arrangements. If you feel that this letter has been sent to you in error, please contact Community Care at the number listed above. If you live outside the Portland metropolitan area, you may also contact us by calling 1-800-949-1004 ext. 31674. We are honored to be able to assist you with your healthcare needs and look forward to hearing from you.
Sincerely,
Community Care Division VA Portland Health Care System 360-759-1674
David Morrison Douglas MD Chief Health Information Officer
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 10/19/2018 09:58

OTHER CURRENT RISK FACTORS: patient (suicidal ideation and/or recent/past attempts) Additional Comments:
PROTECTIVE FACTORS:

------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/19/2018 09:16 AM From: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST To: Douglas D_My HealtheVet _Portland_% Subject: Blood Pressure
Dear Dr. Douglas: I have been tracking my BP at home like you asked me to. I have attached the results.
My BP is consistently between 140 and 160 over 90. Should I be doing anything differently with my meds?
Test Test Tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/19/2018 09:48 AM From: DOUGLAS, DAVID To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: Blood Pressure
Dear Veteran: Dr. Douglas has initiated a blood pressure protocol for you since you stopped Atenolol and started Hydrochlorothiazide.
Since your BP is still high and your potassium last week was normal, we are going to increase the hydrochlorothiazide from 12.5mg daily to 25mg daily.
You will need to come to the lab 2 weeks from today to check another potassium.
Florence Nightingale Nurse Manager for Dr. Douglas
**HCTZ** Initiate the following protocol for MHV Test Patient
Vital Signs: 134/83 (10/03/2017 16:47) 134/83 (10/03/2017 16:47) 72 (10/03/2017 16:47)
GOAL: Less than 130/80 (Due to DM, CAD, or GFR < 60)
----------------------------------------------------------- SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS: Stop atenolol.
INSTRUCTIONS: 1. Confirm pill strength with patient. 2. Remind patient to call prior to scheduled follow up if necessary. 3. Chem 7 q 2 weeks after each dose change. 4. At each contact if BP is greater than goal AND potassium is greater than 3.5 then increase HCTZ dose as noted:
-------------------------------------------------------------
HCTZ 12.5 mg po daily, then in 2 weeks increase to HCTZ 25 mg po daily then end protocol. ------------------------------------------------------------- NOTIFY PROVIDER IF ANY OF THE FOLLOWING OCCUR: 1. Potassium is less than 3.5. 2. Patient does not tolerate medication. 3. Patient is non-adherent with NCM follow up.
COMPLETE CONSULT IF ANY OF THE FOLLOWING CRITERIA ARE MET: 1. BP goal is achieved. 2. Final dose attained. *Update prescription in CPRS for provider signature.

LOCAL TITLE: HOME HEALTH/HOME CARE - CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: HOME HEALTH NOTE DATE OF NOTE: JAN 05, 2018@14:35 ENTRY DATE: JAN 05, 2018@14:36:02 AUTHOR: POOLE,JULIA A EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
HOME HEALTH REFERRAL: MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST PATIENTR is referred to: Connected Healthcare (503) 261-8599 Fax:(503) 408-8932 for home health services following hospitalization for COPD and CHF.
Goals for home health care include: enable pt/CG to safely manage medications, care in home home environment deemed safe for care needs identify need for other services/resources prevent falls and injury maximize mobility and strength, ADLs appropriate adaptive equipment will be in place identify other services, community resources, and planning appropriate to care needs
SERVICES ORDERED: SKILLED NURSING ORDERS Instruction/Supervision of Medications. Assess systems. Teach Disease/Post Hospital Management. Assess adequacy of home environment and patient/caregiver ability to provide care. Instruct/supervise diabetic management. Instruct pt/caregiver re: bowel regimen:
PHYSICAL THERAPY Home Safety/Fall Risk Assessment Prosthetic/Orthotic Evaluation Fall Prevention Gait training Energy conservation training
OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY Home Safety/Fall Risk Assessment Evaluate need for ADL/self care retraining Evaluate need for equipment Teach functional exercises Fall prevention
MEDICAL SOCIAL WORKER Evaluate home/financial/community resources Provide information and referral to needed resources Establish long term care plan Assist with placement in alternate living facility
Reimbursement is via VA pay due to no other insurance benefit to cover home health.
Home health services are ordered by Dr David Douglas.
SIGNING PROVIDER for Home Health Treatment Plan/485 Dr. Dr David Douglas
Anticipated start of care for home health is 1/9/18 with soonest available visit requested.
Please contact Community Health at 31740 for questions or concerns.
/es/ JULIA (JILL) POOLE BSN RN-BC Community Health Coordinator Nurse Signed: 01/05/2018 14:38
Receipt Acknowledged By: 01/26/2018 13:07 /es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIA

approvedBy.name: POOLE,JULIA A
approvedBy.signature: JULIA (JILL) POOLE BSN RN-BC Community Health Coordinator Nurse

------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/31/2017 03:11 PM From: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST To: Douglas D_My HealtheVet _Portland_% Subject: General Inquiry
I recently received an insurance card. How do I get the information to the VA?
Test Test Tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/31/2017 03:13 PM From: DOUGLAS, David To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: General Inquiry
Thank you for contacting the Health Resource Center with your billing questions through Secure Messaging.
To update your insurance on file there are a few options. The easiest option is for you to take a picture of both sides of your insurance card, save it as a pdf and then send it to us as an attachment to a secure message.
Alternatively, you can go to your local facility and give them the card, or you can print the information on your yearly Means Test form, or you can call the Health Resource Center at (866)290-4618. If you choose to update your insurance on file using Secure Messaging we will need the following information from your Insurance Card.
Name of Insurance:
Name on Policy:
(If not the veteran) Date of Birth:
Relationship to Veteran:
Policy/ID Number:
Effective Date:
Group Name:
Group Number:
Rx BIN:
Rx PCN
Type of Insurance:
Billing Address:
Insurance Phone Number:
David Morrison Douglas MD Chief Health Information Officer
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 03/31/2017 12:13

LOCAL TITLE: SURGERY SECURE MESSAGING STANDARD TITLE: SURGERY SECURE MESSAGING DATE OF NOTE: MAR 03, 2017@11:40 ENTRY DATE: MAR 03, 2017@08:41:22 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/02/2017 04:02 PM From: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST To: Liver/Kidney Transplant_Portland VAMC_+ Subject: can a liver transplant patient get a flu shot?
Dear PCP: As you know, I had a liver transplant last year at Portland. When I was there someone told me I should not get a regular flu shot but needed a special flu shot. Is that true? Can I just get my flu shot here in the hospital at Spokane?
Test Test Tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/03/2017 11:36 AM From: MCARTHUR, ALAN To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: can a liver transplant patient get a flu shot?
Yes we can take care of that here in Spokane. I will transfer your secured message to the Transplant folks Portland.
Alan McArthur Mann-Grandstaff VAMC, MHV Coordinator
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/03/2017 11:39 AM From: DOUGLAS, David To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: can a liver transplant patient get a flu shot?
Dear Veteran: You have asked an important question. Flu shots are inactivated vaccines. Because flu can be very serious, particularly in immunosuppressed patients, we ecommend that transplant recipients receive flu shots yearly in the fall; transplant recipients should wait at least three months after transplantation before getting a flu shot but you are now more than 7 months out from your transplant. People who are allergic to eggs or chickens should not get flu shots. Sincerely, Dr. Gunnar
David Morrison Douglas MD Chief Health Information Officer
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 03/03/2017 08:41

approvedBy.name: DOUGLAS,DAVID M
approvedBy.signature: DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST

noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING DATE OF NOTE: MAR 01, 2017@15:23 ENTRY DATE: MAR 01, 2017@12:24:27 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/01/2017 03:21 PM From: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST To: Douglas D_My HealtheVet _Portland_% Subject: ALLERGIES
Dr. Douglas: Remember last year at this time my allergies began acting up? Well they have come back with a vengeance. My eyes are watering and my nose is all stuffed up. Is there any chance I could have some more of that nasal spray you prescribed that worked so well?
Test Test Tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 03/01/2017 03:23 PM From: DOUGLAS, David To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: ALLERGIES
Dear Veteran: Your history suggests a recurrence of seasonal allergic rhinitis. The spray I prescribed last year was a nasal corticosteroid called Fluticasone. I have ordered a new prescription and marked it for next day delivery via UPS. Let me know if this doesn't clear up your symptoms.
David Morrison Douglas MD Chief Health Information Officer
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 03/01/2017 12:24

approvedBy.name: DOUGLAS,DAVID M
approvedBy.signature: DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST

INTERNAL MEDICINE CLINIC NOTE
PROBLEM LIST:
_________________________________________________________ SUBJECTIVE: Mr. XXX is a XXX year-old man who presents for follow-up to discuss the following:
#
ALL: PENICILLIN, LISINOPRIL, SULFA DRUGS, EGGS, MAALOX ANTACID, ADHESIVE TAPE TETRACYCLINE
Active and Recently Expired Outpatient Medications (excluding Supplies):
Active Outpatient Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) ACETAMINOPHEN 325MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH ACTIVE (S) EVERY DAY AS NEEDED *DO NOT TAKE MORE THAN 4,000MG A DAY OF ACETAMINOPHEN FROM ALL SOURCES DUE TO RISK OF LIVER DAMAGE. FOR PAIN. 2) ALOH/MGOH/SIMTH XTRA STRENGTH SUSP TAKE 1 TEASPOONFUL ACTIVE (S) (=5 ML) BY MOUTH EVERY EVENING 3) MAGNESIUM HYDROXIDE SUSP TAKE 1 TABLESPOONFUL (=15 ACTIVE (S) ML) BY MOUTH EVERY DAY
Pending Outpatient Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) ASPIRIN 81MG EC TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY PENDING DAY 2) OMEPRAZOLE 20MG EC CAP TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH PENDING EVERY MORNING BEFORE BREAKFAST
Inactive Outpatient Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) DOCUSATE NA 100MG CAP TAKE ONE CAPSULE BY MOUTH EVERY EXPIRED DAY FOR 3 DAYS, THEN TAKE ONE CAPSULE TWICE A DAY
Active Non-VA Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) Non-VA ASPIRIN 325MG TAB 325MG MOUTH FOUR TIMES A DAY ACTIVE 2) Non-VA ATORVASTATIN CALCIUM TAB EVERY EVENING ACTIVE 3) Non-VA FISH OIL CAP/TAB MOUTH ACTIVE 4) Non-VA GINKGO BILOBA MODERATE AMOUNT MOUTH EVERY DAY ACTIVE 5) Non-VA HORSE CHESTNUT CAP/TAB MOUTH TWICE A DAY ACTIVE 6) Non-VA WARFARIN NA (GOLDEN STATE) 2MG TAB 2MG MOUTH ACTIVE AS DIRECTED
12 Total Medications
OBJECTIVE VITAL SIGNS:
General: alert, well-appearing in no acute distress HEENT: sclera anicteric, MMM Neck: JVP not appreciated, no LAD CV: RRR, no murmur Lungs: clear Abd: soft, nontender, +BS Ext: no LE edema Skin: warm, dry Neuro: nonfocal, normal gait

Suicide Risk Assessment Determination of a positive preliminary risk assessment should be a clinical decision based on the Veterans answers to the preliminary risk assessment questions. Full assessment is required because Veteran is being admitted or establishing care with the Mental Health Service Line. Detailed Suicide Risk Assessment:
CURRENT WARNING SIGNS AND RISK FACTORS:
Social/demographic risk factors (check all that apply):
Current psychosocial stressors/recent losses (check all that apply):
Access to guns? Comment:
PROTECTIVE FACTORS:
Given the veteran's presentation at the time of this assessment and considering the above noted risk and protective factors, in my clinical judgment the veteran's current risk potential for suicidal behavior is: HIGH RISK.
PLAN OF CARE:

noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: SUICIDE RISK EVALUATION - COMPREHENSIVE STANDARD TITLE: SUICIDE PREVENTION RISK ASSESSMENT SCREENING NOT DATE OF NOTE: APR 19, 2016@12:40 ENTRY DATE: APR 19, 2016@12:41:05 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Suicide Risk Assessment Are you feeling hopeless about the present or future? YES Have you had thoughts of taking your life? YES When did you have these thoughts? Do you have a plan to take your life? YES Have you ever had a suicide attempt? YES Description\Dates: Determination of a positive preliminary risk assessment should be a clinical decision based on the Veterans answers to the preliminary risk assessment questions. Patient exhibits signs of risk Detailed Suicide Risk Assessment:
CURRENT WARNING SIGNS AND RISK FACTORS: Ideation, Current alcohol and/or drug use, Purposelessness
Social/demographic risk factors (check all that apply): Past suicide attempts, History of self-harm behaviors, Elderly (65+)
Current psychosocial stressors/recent losses (check all that apply): Marriage difficulties
Access to guns? Comment:
PROTECTIVE FACTORS: Positive social support
Given the veteran's presentation at the time of this assessment and considering the above noted risk and protective factors, in my clinical judgment the veteran's current risk potential for suicidal behavior is: HIGH RISK.
PLAN OF CARE: Escorted the veteran to ER for psychiatric evaluation for admission.
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 04/19/2016 12:42

approvedBy.name: DOUGLAS,DAVID M
approvedBy.signature: DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST

LOCAL TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH SECURE MESSAGING DATE OF NOTE: FEB 02, 2016@10:01 ENTRY DATE: FEB 02, 2016@07:05:33 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 02/02/2016 09:59 AM From: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST To: Douglas D_My HealtheVet _Portland_% Subject: General Inquiry
Dear Doctor: the Prozac you prescribed 3 weeks ago has improved my mood but I am having a hard time sleeping. When I lay down to bed my mind is working overtime and I just can't drift off to sleep. Is there something that will help this??
Test test tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 02/02/2016 10:01 AM From: DOUGLAS, David To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: General Inquiry
Dear Sleepless in Portland: You are reporting insomnia which sometimes happens as a side effect of anti-depressants like Prozac. We often treat this with low doses of a medication called Trazadone. I will mail out a prescription of Trazadone 50mg at bedtime. Let me know if this improves your sleep.
David Morrison Douglas MD Chief Health Information Officer
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 02/02/2016 07:05

approvedBy.name: DOUGLAS,DAVID M
approvedBy.signature: DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST

LOCAL TITLE: DENTISTRY SECURE MESSAGING STANDARD TITLE: DENTISTRY SECURE MESSAGING DATE OF NOTE: JAN 04, 2016@09:53 ENTRY DATE: JAN 04, 2016@07:14:45 AUTHOR: SMITH,GREGORY EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** DENTISTRY SECURE MESSAGING Has ADDENDA ***
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 01/04/2016 08:10 AM From: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST To: Dental Service_Portland VAMC_# Subject: General Inquiry
Dear Dr. Smith, Remember that tooth you removed 10 days ago? Well, the tooth right next to it has a filling and it seems like it is now loose. I keep running my tongue along the filling and it moves. Is this serious? What should I do?
Test test tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 01/04/2016 08:58 AM From: SMITH, GREGORY To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: General Inquiry
Dear Veteran, Thank you for contacting me. I reviewed your X-rays and you do have a restoration (filling) on the tooth next to the one we removed. My records also indicate that this restoration is more than 10 years old and is likely failing. The recent X-rays do not show decay (cavity), but because the restoration is loose, we need to replace it. I will ask our scheduling assistant to make an appointment for a new restoration. In the meantime, please do not eat sticky foods or hard candy and continue to brush your teeth after meals and floss before bedtime.
If you experience any pain that is not relieved with over the counter pain medications, please contact me immediately.
Gregory M. Smith, D.D.S. Associate Director, Dental Informatics and Analytics
/es/ GREGORY M SMITH
Signed: 01/04/2016 07:14
01/14/2016 ADDENDUM STATUS: COMPLETED Patient Name: MHVZZVISNTWENTY,TEST, DOB: 01/01/2001, Age: 15 Visit: V: Jan 04, 2016@09:53 POR-SECMSG-DENTAL-X. Primary PCE Diagnosis: K08.50 (Unsatisfactory Restoration of Tooth, unspecified). Dental Category: 15-OPC, Class IV. Treatment Status: Active.

Dear Dr. Douglas: The Prozac you prescribed has definitely helped my mood. The problem is it has seemed to make it harder for me to fall asleep. When I lay down, I just can't seem to drift off to sleep. What should I do?
Test test tester
------Original Message------------------------ Sent: 10/23/2015 03:21 PM From: DOUGLAS, David To: MHVZZVISNTWENTY, TEST Subject: Medication Inquiry
Difficulty sleeping is a common side effect from Prozac. I will prescribe low dose Trazadone to help you sleep.
David Morrison Douglas MD Chief Health Information Officer

Hello, Mr/Mrs/Ms__________. This is ____________ your healthcare team at the VA and we hope that you are feeling better since your recent hospitalization. During that stay your provider may have talked with you about your use of tobacco. We are following up with you about that conversation. If it is OK with you, please answer the following questions and return your answers to your healthcare team: 1. Did your provider refer you to counseling sessions to help you stop using tobacco; and if so, are you planning to participate? x Declined to provide information regarding counseling participation. ? NOT referred. ? Referred and is NOT participating. ? Referred and plans to participate, but the first session has not occurred yet. ? Referred and is participating. ? Would like referral. [Online? And refer to PCP?: process?]
2. Did your provider offer you medication for tobacco use cessation; and if so are you taking the medication as directed?
Given medication and NOT taking as directed.
3. As of today, have you made any changes to your tobacco use? ? Declined to provide information regarding tobacco use status. ? Tobacco use is unchanged. ? Has quit using tobacco. x Has reduced the amount of tobacco used from __2/day_____ to ___1/day_____.

1. How often did you have a drink containing alcohol in the past year? Four or more times a week
2. How many drinks containing alcohol did you have on a typical day when you were drinking in the past year? 3 or 4
3. How often did you have six or more drinks on one occasion in the past year? Less than monthly Pt drinks above recommended alcohol limits. Medical problems associated with alcohol use were reviewed with the patient. Specifically the following were reviewed: Hypertension, liver disease, seizures, depression The patient was advised about recommended limits and to drink below them. Will discuss again at next visit. Provider discussed and offered treatment. Patient agrees to treatment. For a scheduled evaluation, call 503-220-8262 x31841 and an appointment will be made for the patient. Patient given scheduling information. Patient's response to counseling: Agrees to limit drinking as follows: Max: 3 drinks per week Max: 1 drinks per occasion. Diabetes or HTN > 139/89: Repeat BP: 198/122 Thiazides considered and not appropriate because: gout
Patient has limited life expectancy. The patient declines the recommended changes in medications to improve BP control. Comment: jn/. Specific recommendations for lifestyle modifications were made to the patient to improve BP control. The patient was educated on the importance of taking prescribed therapy for hypertension. Pressure Ulcer Risk Provider: Patient reports current or history of pressure ulcer(s). A skin assessment was performed and the patient's skin is intact. Pressure ulcer assesssment: Location: Size: Nonblanchable erythema: No Full Thickness: No Woundbed color: Red %: Yellow %: Black %: Other %: Surrounding skin erythema? No Drainage? No Undermined edges? Yes Plan: iuhi
Dressing frequency: qd *Vitals: Pain: 0 What does your pain level need to be for you to experience rest and comfort: No, patient verbalized no need to address pain/comfort issues at this visit.

LOCAL TITLE: MHD - INDIVIDUAL NOTE STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH OUTPATIENT NOTE DATE OF NOTE: APR 09, 2014@08:05 ENTRY DATE: APR 09, 2014@08:05:29 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
CLINICAL REMINDER ACTIVITY Homelessness Screening: In the past 2 months, have you been living in stable housing that you own, rent, or stay in as part of a household? No - Not living in stable housing. Where have you lived for MOST of the past 2 months? Anywhere outside, eg. Street, Vehicle, Abandoned Building Comment: under a bridge Would you like to be REFERRED to talk more about your housing situation? Patient agrees to referral What's the best way to reach you? How to reach: this is only a test *Alcohol Use Screen (AUDIT-C): SCREEN FOR ALCOHOL (AUDIT-C) An alcohol screening test (AUDIT-C ) was positive (score=12).
1. How often did you have a drink containing alcohol in the past year? Four or more times a week
2. How many drinks containing alcohol did you have on a typical day when you were drinking in the past year? 10 or more
3. How often did you have six or more drinks on one occasion in the past year? Daily or almost daily *Education Assessment: SPEECH AND LANGUAGE Patient reports preferred healthcare language is English. PATIENT EDUCATION ASSESSMENT Unable to do assessment. Reason: comatose *Military Sexual Trauma: When you were in the military:
1) Did you ever receive uninvited or unwanted sexual attention (i.e., touching, cornering, pressure for sexual favors or inappropriate verbal remarks, etc.)?
2) Did anyone ever use force or the threat of force to have sex with you against your will?
Patient was asked "While you were in the military did you experience sexual harassment, assault or rape?"
TEST MHVZZVISNTWENTY responded yes.
MST screening/database information reviewed/provided. Provider discussed counseling/treatment options with TEST MHVZZVISNTWENTY. Handout given to patient. *Nurse/MA BP > 139/89: Repeat BP: 210/140 *Pressure Ulcer Risk Screen: Does the Veteran report a history of pressure ulcers or current pressure ulcer(s)? YES - Provider must do a complete skin assessment.
Does the Veteran have medical device(s)? YES - Provider must do a focused skin assessment. Splint
Is the Veteran bed-confined or a wheelchair user? YES - Provider must consider performing a skin assessement.
Does the Veteran require assistance to transfer/change position? YES - Provider must consider performing a skin assessment. *Vitals: Pain: 10 Location/Duration: lower back What does your pain level need to be for you to experience rest and comfort: Amputation Risk Assessment: Diabetic Amputation Risk Assessment = LEVEL 3 - HIGH RISK Individuals at Level 3, high risk, demonstrate at least one of the following: Peripheral neuropathy with sensory loss (inability to perceive the Semmes-Weinstein 5.07 monofilament) AND diminished circulation and foot deformity or minor foot infection (and a diagnosis of diabetes). Prior ulcer, osteomyelitis, or history of prior amputation. End-stage Renal Disease Diabetes or HTN > 139/89: Repeat BP: 210/140
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 04/09/2014 08:14

approvedBy.signature: DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST

LOCAL TITLE: SUICIDE RISK EVALUATION - COMPREHENSIVE STANDARD TITLE: SUICIDE PREVENTION RISK ASSESSMENT SCREENING NOT DATE OF NOTE: MAR 04, 2014@10:51 ENTRY DATE: MAR 04, 2014@10:51:33 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Suicide Risk Assessment Are you feeling hopeless about the present or future? YES Have you had thoughts of taking your life? YES When did you have these thoughts? Do you have a plan to take your life? YES Have you ever had a suicide attempt? YES Description\Dates: Determination of a positive preliminary risk assessment should be a clinical decision based on the Veterans answers to the preliminary risk assessment questions. Patient exhibits signs of risk Detailed Suicide Risk Assessment:
CURRENT WARNING SIGNS AND RISK FACTORS: Ideation
Social/demographic risk factors (check all that apply): White
Current psychosocial stressors/recent losses (check all that apply): Employment difficulties , Financial difficulties
Access to guns? Comment:
PROTECTIVE FACTORS: Reality testing ability, Positive coping skills
Given the veteran's presentation at the time of this assessment and considering the above noted risk and protective factors, in my clinical judgment the veteran's current risk potential for suicidal behavior is: HIGH RISK.
PLAN OF CARE: Suicide Safety Plan completed/ or existing Safety Plan reviewed and updated. Family member/significant other informed and involved in plan. Escorted the veteran to ER for psychiatric evaluation for admission. Patient directly admitted to appropriate Psychiatry Inpatient Service (patient directly observed until evaluated by admitting physician). Involuntary commitment procedures initiated.
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 03/04/2014 11:13

LOCAL TITLE: C&P MENTAL DISORDERS STANDARD TITLE: C & P EXAMINATION NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 11, 2014@13:00 ENTRY DATE: MAR 06, 2014@14:27:39 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
COMPENSATION AND PENSION EXAMINATION MENTAL DISORDERS (EXCEPT PTSD AND EATING DISORDERS) ===================================================
MEDICAL HISTORY =============== IS THIS EXAMINATION FOR REVIEW OF AN ALREADY SERVICE-CONNECTED MENTAL DISORDER? Yes
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
--------------------
TREATMENT --------- WAS THERE OUTPATIENT TREATMENT FOR A MD DISORDER: No
HOSPITALIZATION(S) ------------------ WERE THERE ONE/MORE HOSPITALIZATIONS FOR A MD DISORDER: No
PRESENT MEDICAL HISTORY ----------------------- ARE THERE MEDICAL AND/OR PSYCHIATRIC SYMPTOMS (OTHER THEN PTSD) PRESENT DURING PAST YEAR? Yes IS THERE CURRENT TREATMENT FOR A MENTAL DISORDER? No FREQUENCY, SEVERITY, AND DURATION OF NON-PTSD PSYCHIATRIC/MEDICAL SYMPTOMS: this is only a test
PSYCH EXAM ========== GENERAL APPEARANCE: Neatly groomed
PSYCHOMOTOR ACTIVITY: Repetitive Acts
SPEECH: Rapid
ATTITUDE TOWARD EXAMINER: Attentive
AFFECT: Inappropriate
MOOD: Happy, Expansive
ATTENTION: Attention Disturbance (Easily Distracted) ABLE TO DO SERIAL 7'S? Yes ABLE TO SPELL A WORD FORWARD AND BACKWARD? Yes
ORIENTATION: INTACT TO PERSON: Yes
INTACT TO TIME: Yes
INTACT TO PLACE: Yes
THOUGHT PROCESS: Paucity of ideas
THOUGHT CONTENT: Phobias
DELUSIONS: Nihilistic delusions (part of body is missing) ARE DELUSIONS PERSISTENT? Yes
JUDGMENT: Does not understand outcome of behavior
INTELLIGENCE: Average
INSIGHT: Patient partially understands that he/she has a problem.
DOES THE PATIENT HAVE SLEEP IMPAIRMENT? Yes
TYPE OF HALLUCINATIONS: Olfactory ARE HALLUCINATIONS PERSISTENT? Yes
DOES THE PATIENT HAVE INAPPROPRIATE BEHAVIOR? No
INTERPRETS PROVERBS APPROPRIATELY? No
DOES THE PATIENT HAVE OBSESSIVE/RITUALISTIC BEHAVIOR? Yes
DOES THE PATIENT HAVE PANIC ATTACKS? Yes
IS THERE PRESENCE OF SUICIDAL THOUGHTS? Yes
EXTENT OF IMPULSE CONTROL: Fair EPISODES OF VIOLENCE: Yes
ABILITY TO MAINTAIN MINIMUM PERSONAL HYGIENE? No
IS THERE PROBLEM WITH ACTIVITIES OF DAILY LIVING: No
MEMORY ------ REMOTE MEMORY: Normal RECENT MEMORY: Mildly Impaired IMMEDIATE MEMORY: Normal EXAMPLE(S) OF MEMORY DISORDER: this is only a test
TESTS ===== PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTING --------------------- NAME(S) OF PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTING CARRIED OUT AND DESCRIPTION OF RESULTS: rohrschach COMMENT ON VALIDITY OF TEST RESULTS: Valid WERE RESULTS OF TESTING TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT IN THE EXAMINATION REPORT? Yes
SOCIAL WORK SURVEY ------------------ WERE SOCIAL WORK SURVEY RESULTS TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION IN THE DIAGNOSIS/ASSESSMENT? Yes COMMENTS ON SOCIAL WORK SURVEY: this is only a test WERE ALL TESTS RESULTS INCLUDED ON THE EXAM REPORT? Yes
DIAGNOSIS =========
MENTAL DISORDER: MENTAL COMPETENCY ---------------------------------- DOES THE VETERAN KNOW THE AMOUNT OF THEIR BENEFIT PAYMENT? No DOES THE VETERAN KNOW THE AMOUNTS OF MONTHLY BILLS? No DOES THE VETERAN PRUDENTLY HANDLE PAYMENTS? No DOES THE VETERAN PERSONALLY HANDLE MONEY AND PAYS BILLS? No
IS THE VETERAN CAPABLE OF MANAGING FINANCIAL AFFAIRS? No
IS A SOCIAL WORK ASSESSMENT NECESSARY TO RENDER AN OPINION? No
MENTAL DISORDER: EMPLOYMENT HISTORY -------------------------------- USUAL OCCUPATION: farmer IS THE VETERAN CURRENTLY EMPLOYED? No IS VETERAN RETIRED? No IS VETERAN UNEMPLOYED BUT NOT RETIRED? Unsure AXIS I: ptsd AXIS II: none AXIS III: hypertension AXIS IV: unemployed AXIS V: GLOBAL ASSESSMENT OF FUNCTIONING ---------------------------------------- SCORE: 86 TIME FRAME: OTHER COMMENTS: this is only a test
DOES EACH DIAGNOSIS OF MENTAL DISORDER MEET THE DSM-IV DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA? Yes
RESOLUTION OF DIAGNOSIS: A new clinical condition
PSYCH SUMMARY =============
EFFECTS OF MENTAL DISORDER ON OCCUPATIONAL AND SOCIAL FUNCTIONING ----------------------------------------------------------------- IS THERE TOTAL OCCUPATIONAL AND SOCIAL IMPAIRMENT DUE TO MENTAL DISORDER SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS? Yes EXAMPLES AND PERTINENT SYMPTOMS, INCLUDING THOSE ALREADY REPORTED: this is only a test
WAS A MEDICAL OPINION REQUESTED? No
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 03/06/2014 14:27

LOCAL TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH DIAGNOSTIC STUDY NOTE STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH DIAGNOSTIC STUDY NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 05, 2014@08:52:13 ENTRY DATE: FEB 05, 2014@08:52:13 AUTHOR: MINIUM,WILLIAM D EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
. Montreal Cognitive Assessment, Alternate 2
Date Given: 02/05/2014 Clinician: Minium,William D Location: Mh2i Gpd Mh Cwt/Hvsep
Veteran: Mhvzzvisntwenty, Test SSN: xxx-xx-2000 DOB: Jan 1,2001 (13) Gender: Male
MoCA Score: 15 A score of 26 or greater is considered normal.
Questions and Answers
1. Alternating Trail Making. Correct Pattern: 1-A- 2- B- 3- C- 4- D- 5- E, without drawing any lines that cross. Any error that is not immediately self-corrected is scored incorrect. Correct 2. Cylinder-Visuoconstructional Skills. Correct: All must be present: three-dimensional, all lines are drawn, no line is added, lines are relatively parallel and their length is similar. Incorrect 3. Draw a clock 3A. Clock face must be a circle with only minor distortion acceptable (e.g., slight imperfection on closing the circle). Correct circle 3B. All clock numbers must be present with no additional numbers; numbers must be in the correct order and placed in the approximate quadrants on the clock face; Roman numerals are acceptable; numbers can be placed outside the circle contour. Incorrect 3C. There must be two hands jointly indicating the correct time; the hour hand must be clearly shorter than the minute hand; hands must be centered within the clock face with their junction close to the clock center. Correct clock hands 4. Name pictured animals 4A. Donkey Incorrect 4B. Pig Correctly named pig 4C. Kangaroo Incorrect 5. Attention 5A. Forward Digit Span. Correct forward digit span 5B. Backward Digit Span. Correct response for the backwards trial is 1-7-4. Incorrect 5C. Vigilance. Correct when there is zero to one errors (an error is a tap on a wrong letter or a failure to tap on letter A). Correct vigilance 5D. Serial 7s starting at 80. Continue for five responses. Two or three correct subtractions 6. Language 6A. Sentence repetition. She heard his lawyer was the one to sue after the accident. Correctly repeated 6B. Sentence repetition. The little girls who were given too much candy got stomach aches. Incorrect 7. Words beginning with the letter B. Correct: more than 10 words in one minute. 8. Abstraction 8A. Similarity between EYE - EAR. Incorrect 8B. Similarity between TRUMPET - PIANO. Correct 9. Delayed recall 9A. Recall TRAIN Incorrect 9B. Recall EGG. Correctly recalled 9C. Recall HAT. Incorrect 9D. Recall CHAIR. Correctly recalled 9E. Recall BLUE. Incorrect 10. Orientation 10A. Today's date, Correct 10B. Current month Incorrect 10C. Current year Correct 10D. Day of the week Incorrect 10E. What place is this? Correct 10F. What city are we in? Incorrect 11. Years of formal education: Twelve years or fewer.
Copyright (c) Z. Nasreddine MD
Information contained in this note is based on a self-report assessment and is not sufficient to use alone for diagnostic purposes. Assessment results should be verified for accuracy and used in conjunction with other diagnostic activities and procedures.
/es/ Willy Minium MHD PROGRAM SPECIALIST Signed: 02/05/2014 08:52

approvedBy.name: MINIUM,WILLIAM D
approvedBy.signature: Willy Minium MH Program Analyst

LOCAL TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH DIAGNOSTIC STUDY NOTE STANDARD TITLE: MENTAL HEALTH DIAGNOSTIC STUDY NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 05, 2014@08:50:18 ENTRY DATE: FEB 05, 2014@08:50:18 AUTHOR: MINIUM,WILLIAM D EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Patient Health Questionnaire - 9 (PHQ-9)
Date Given: 02/05/2014 Clinician: Minium,William D Location: Mh2i Gpd Mh Cwt/Hvsep
Veteran: Mhvzzvisntwenty, Test SSN: xxx-xx-2000 DOB: Jan 1,2001 (13) Gender: Male
PHQ-9 Depression Scale Score: 12
Guide for Interpreting PHQ-9 scores: 0-4: The score suggests the patient may not need depression treatment. 5-14: Physician uses clinical judgment about treatment based on patient's duration of symptoms and functional impairment. 15 or more: Warrants treatment for depression, using antidepressant, psychotherapy and/or a combination of treatment.
Questions and Answers
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems? 1. Little interest or pleasure in doing things Not at all 2. Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless Several days 3. Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much More than half the days 4. Feeling tired or having little energy Nearly every day 5. Poor appetite or overeating Not at all 6. Feeling bad about yourself or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down Several days 7. Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television More than half the days 8. Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual Nearly every day 9. Thoughts that you would be better off dead or of hurting yourself in some way Not at all 10. If you checked off any problems, how DIFFICULT have these problems made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home or get along with other people? Somewhat difficult
Information contained in this note is based on a self report assessment and is not sufficient to use alone for diagnostic purposes. Assessment results should be verified for accuracy and used in conjunction with other diagnostic activities.

LOCAL TITLE: DERM - NEW WITH PROCEDURE STANDARD TITLE: DERMATOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 19, 2013@09:57 ENTRY DATE: FEB 19, 2013@09:57:55 AUTHOR: HARKINS,MAURICE A EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
PHOTOGRAPH TAKEN & UPLOADED INTO VISTA IMAGING Punch Biopsy-4mm Time out checklist completed immediately prior to procedure. Procedure, alternatives, risks, and questions were discussed with the patient, and written consent was obtained. The skin was cleaned with ChloraPrep and infiltrated with 1% lidocaine with epinephrine. Punch biopsy was performed, and the wound was closed with 4-0 nylon interrupted sutures. Wound was dressed with petrolatum and Band-Aid. There were no complications. Sutures to be removed in 2 weeks. Suture removal kit and instructions provided to patient. Wound care instructions provided to patient. Specimen(s) sent to pathology.
Testing CPRS note input
/es/ Maurice A HARKINS
Signed: 02/19/2013 10:02

approvedBy.signature: Maurice "Alex" HARKINS My HealtheVet

LOCAL TITLE: PC - FOLLOW UP STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE OUTPATIENT NOTE DATE OF NOTE: NOV 21, 2012@17:19 ENTRY DATE: NOV 21, 2012@17:19:46 AUTHOR: WOODS,SUSAN S EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Test Patient with Test complains coming to Test clinic for follow-up of
PROBLEM LIST 1. Hypertension 2. Diabetes 3. Elevated LDL 4. Hx tobacco use
_________________________________________________________ SUBJECTIVE
The patient is a 11 yo MALE that presents today to address the following:
no specific issues today. Reports taking medications as prescribed. attempting to engage in physical activity
Goal: wants to reduce 10 lbs. Life goal: see his grandkids
ROS - all negative
ALL: PENICILLIN, LISINOPRIL, SULFA DRUGS, EGGS, MAALOX ANTACID
MEDS: Active Medications: 1) Ibuprofen 400mg tab take one tablet by mouth three active times a day 2) Lisinopril 10mg tab take one tablet by mouth every active day for blood pressure 3) Multivitamin tab take 1 tablet by mouth every day active 4) Ranitidine 150mg tab take one tablet by mouth twice a active day 5) Simvastatin 80mg tab take one-half tablet by mouth at active bedtime to lower your cholesterol. avoid consuming grapefruit products. 6) Trazodone hcl 50mg tab take one-half tablet by mouth active at bedtime as needed
active non-va medications status ========================================================================= 1) Non-va atorvastatin calcium tab every evening 2) Non-va fish oil cap/tab mouth 3) Non-va ginkgo biloba moderate amount mouth every day
9 total medications)
The patient's medication profile was reviewed and updated; the patient was given a hard copy of the updated information today prior to departure.
OBJECTIVE BP 117/60 HR 65
GEN: appears well HEENT: unremarkable COR: RRR no mgr PULM: clear bilaterally EXT: no edema SKIN: scattered SK on ears, hands
_________________________________________________________ LABS
LAST CREATININE: CREATININE 1.0 12/02/2011 09:53 ESTIMATED CLEARANCE: The OBJECT LAB-CREATININE CLEARANCE is INACTIVE...Contact IRM.
_________________________________________________________ PREVENTION: Lipid Panel: 12/02/11 09:54 CHOLESTEROL 119 HDL CHOLESTEROL 65 LDL-CHOL CALC 120 TRIGLYCERIDES 45
LAST COLON CA SCREEN: No guaiac results in the last year
LAST PSA: No PROSTATIC SPECIFIC ANTIGEN in the last 1Y
VACCINATIONS: IMMUNIZATIONS - No immunizations on file
HEP C STATUS: No HEPC ANTIBODY (SEE PANEL #6727) in the last 1Y
_________________________________________________________ STUDIES:
_________________________________________________________
ASSESSMENT/PLAN:
1. HTN blood pressure self-care and self-monitoring is excellent. continue current Rx regimen.
2. HLD patient agrees to attend Heart Health class.
_________________________________________________________ DISPO: 1. MEDS: none 2. LABS: none 3. STUDIES: none 4. CONSULTS: none 5. NCM instructions: none 6. Facilitator instructions: none 7. Education: Education and counselling provided on pertinent aspects of current medical problems. Questions answered. 8. F/U: 1 year or sooner PRN 9. Use MHV secure email as needed for non-urgent issues.
/es/ SUSAN S WOODS MD STAFF PHYSICIAN Signed: 11/21/2012 17:27

approvedBy.signature: SUSAN S WOODS MD STAFF PHYSICIAN

noteTO.text:
LOCAL TITLE: BENZODIAZEPINE TREATMENT AGREEMENT STANDARD TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL MEDICINE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: FEB 16, 2012@15:17 ENTRY DATE: FEB 16, 2012@15:18:04 AUTHOR: DOUGLAS,DAVID M EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
TREATMENT AGREEMENT FOR USE OF BENZODIAZEPINE MEDICATIONS
Veteran was given a copy of this agreement, and a signed copy will be scanned into the medical record:
Treatment Agreement for Chronic Anxiety Management and the Use of Benzodiazepine Medicines
My clinician and I agree that my current symptoms are disabling and may be reduced by use of a benzodiazepine. However, benzodiazepine medications rarely cause such symptoms to go away completely. The goal of using this medication is to reduce symptoms and help improve function in a safe manner. I agree to the following:
1. I understand that benzodiazepine medicines are being prescribed on a trial basis as one part of a treatment plan developed by my clinician and myself. If therapeutic doses of these medicines do not contribute to achievement of our target level of function, they will be discontinued. Improvement in function will be demonstrated by my ability to: ________________________________________________.
2. I will use the medicine at the dose prescribed. Adjustment of dosage will occur only after a discussion with my clinician during a scheduled appointment.
3. My clinician and I have discussed how my benzodiazepine medicine will be refilled. I will follow our agreed upon plan for notifying my clinician if I need to discuss the medicine between scheduled refills.
4. I will obtain benzodiazepine prescriptions from my clinician only and not from other VA clinicians or community providers. If requested, I will provide consent allowing my clinician to communicate with my other clinicians.
5. I will not take a benzodiazepine prescribed to another person and I will not share mine with others.
6. I am responsible for protecting my medicines from damage, loss, or theft. In such instances the medication will not be replaced or refilled early.
7. I will not use my current prescription to treat new symptoms. New symptoms require an evaluation to determine the best treatment. If new symptoms arise, I may call to request an evaluation from my clinician or another clinician in his or her absence.
8. Taking non-prescribed drugs or drinking alcohol together with benzodiazepines can be dangerous, with risk of overdose and death. I will not use non-prescribed drugs while taking benzodiazepines. I have discussed the risks of using alcohol while taking benzodiazepines with my clinician, and we have come to an agreement regarding the use of alcoholic beverages as follows:______________.
9. I agree to periodic testing of urine or blood for drug or alcohol use to ensure I am taking my medication properly.
10. I understand the potential side effects and risks of benzodiazepine medicines, which include: a. psychological and physical dependence b. impaired judgment, thinking, or motor skills c. interaction with prescription or over-the-counter medications.
I agree to inform all of my providers (VA and non-VA) that I am taking benzodiazepine medication as this medication may have interactions with other medications prescribed to me. If I am prescribed a medication that interacts with benzodiazepines, such as pain medications, the benzodiazepine dose may need to be changed or the benzodiazepine may need to be discontinued. I have been warned against operating hazardous machinery, including automobiles, while taking the medication. Because benzodiazepines can be harmful to a fetus, I will notify my clinician if I am pregnant or intend to become pregnant.
By signing below, I am agreeing that I have read this document, I understand it, and I am willing to comply with these standards. Any questions I may have had after reading this information have been answered. If I am unable or unwilling to comply with the terms of this agreement, I understand that it may be medically necessary for my clinician to stop providing me with benzodiazepine medication.
Name: Social Security #: Patient Signature: Date:
Name of Clinician: Clinician signature: Date:
Name of MHPCP: MHPCP signature: [Revised 9/12/11]
/es/ DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 02/16/2012 15:18

approvedBy.name: DOUGLAS,DAVID M
approvedBy.signature: DAVID M. DOUGLAS MD CHIEF HEALTH INFORMATICS OFFICER/ATTENDING PSYCHIATRIST
